What's the best way to contribute to the Documentation and how would I go about doing so?

Good question and I don't know that there is a good answer. I think the only ways to contribute to the documentation are either to request edit access on the specific documentation site (and/or) to simply write up suggestions and post them in the respective issue queue.

Problem For new users it can be difficult and confusing to figure out how to contribute to BackdropCMS. For many people there is an intimidation factor and fear of doing things wrong that prevents ...

backdrop-ops/backdropcms.org
Issue tracker for the BackdropCMS.org website. Contribute to backdrop-ops/backdropcms.org development by creating an account on GitHub.

@jenlampton @StPaulTim I'm wondering if it's time to move documentation outside the main b.org site? We could establish a process to allow people to register accounts and be able to create documentation drafts, or draft new revisions etc. ...then a team of reviewers could publish things. ...I was thinking that we could even consider hosting it in something other than a CMS - something that allows collaborative edits and contributions/reviews etc. like https://readthedocs.org or https://www.gitbook.com which I've seen a lot of open source software use.

https://github.com/backdrop-ops/backdropcms.org/issues/256

Consider using GitHub-based documentation with something like GitBook or ReadTheDocs for the front-end. · Issue #256 · backdrop-ops/backdropcms.org
https://www.gitbook.com/blog/features I particularly like: Simple to update, publish and update your books easily using Git or the web book editor. Version Control, GitBook is based on GIT scm. A s...

Maybe we should have a seperate docs.backdropcms.org website for all documentation (guides, developers, etc.) and just use api.backdropcms.org for actual API code (i.e. code comments). In other words, put all written documentation into a new, better-structured site.
Yeah. I'd be supportive of that ^^ :+1:

In https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues/4802 @indigoxela mentioned that there is a link pointing to a d.org article in one of the messages we are tweaking ...so I've adapted https://www.drupal.org/server-permissions into https://backdropcms.org/user-guide/site-configuration-and-web-hosting-issues and added https://backdropcms.org/user-guide/enabling-and-disabling-phpinfo as a sub-section to it (from https://www.drupal.org/node/243993) in the hope that we can at the same time replace that d.org link with a b.org one

...do note that I've found the tone/language/wording used in https://www.drupal.org/server-permissions extremely alienating and derogatory towards people with less technical knowledge, and insulting the reader’s intelligence; so my adaptations are extensive. Please feel free to review these documents, and provide feedback (or direct-edit them for those of us with permissions).

I quickly skimmed through both documentations and am yet another time impressed by the Backdrop user friendlyness.

I had to swallow with sentences like "Less experienced users will not fully understand what these commands do..." (Drupal), and am happy that there's now a Backdrop version of that doc.

@klonos ++
klonos kudos (Karma: 12)

klonos said:

...do note that I've found the tone/language/wording used in https://www.drupal.org/server-permissions extremely alienating and derogatory towards people with less technical knowledge, and insulting the reader’s intelligence; so my adaptations are extensive. Please feel free to review these documents, and provide feedback (or direct-edit them for those of us with permissions).

Good catch. I think you mean these bits?

Less experienced users will not fully understand what these commands do or why they should do them, and definitely won't know when to deviate from them.

and

Things are more confusing for less experienced users though. The following info is intended to help newbies come to grips with the documentation and their webhosts environment.

I don't think I would have caught the problem with the language that you saw, though I agree. To generalize the approach: in a help doc you should always be talking to the person you are helping, and not about them.

Is that the issue, or is there something else I also didn't notice?

No, that's pretty much the issue ...implying or straight-up saying that new users are stupid or do not understand commands ...when the same thing can be said by completely omitting these phrases/words (which means that there is no value for them being there in the first place) or phrasing things slightly differently. ...also other small things like:

A lot of new Drupal users run into issues getting Drupal to work properly on their webhost."

vs:

New Backdrop users may run into issues getting their site to work properly on their webhost.
...notice the "a lot" vs "may"

I totally agree, and that's the whole reason for the R2W initiative. I don't think people who aren't FEDs should be labeled beginners, just as people who don't know how to design clothes but still want to wear them aren't considered novices either.
